tested cluster system to enable small to midsize businesses (SMBs) to more easily design large-scale networks.
Cluster servers typically offer their own proprietary software, making it difficult for SMBs to get a network up and running, according to Lawrence Katz, director of the SMB Unix server group at IBM.
"With the creation of the system we are offering a pretested small-cluster [server] preoverview with a server and two periphery servers, pre-installed with remote management software," Katz said. "Typically [in these cluster systems] the software has to be installed [by the client]."
IBM also announced the small-scale systems would be made available with new entry-priced servers and a cluster system director board so SMBs can increase the size of the system after purchasing a single small-cluster system.
IBM's Opteron-based system comprises three servers

on Cancer (IARC), a sub-agency of WHO, examined the possible links between colorectal cancer (also referred to as large bowel cancer) and red meat consumption. According to the study by the Lancet Oncology, a large volume of evidence points towards the consumption of red meat being a cause of colorectal cancer. Another similar study published earlier this year also agrees.
During the course of the study, the IARC examined the diets of more than one million people across the world, covering a wide range of cultures and geographical settings. Researchers also analyzed the diets of more than a dozen other people groups across the world.

Asked in a television interview to discuss the impact of fiscal cuts under so-called "sequestration" devised under the plan for raising the debt limit in the near term, Lew likened the approach to a chemical prepackaged as poison so that consumers would know what and how much they are getting.
"The problem with the poison plan is the poison equals a lot of cuts, a tremendous amount of cuts. Whole bunches of Americans are going to get hurt," Lew said on CNN's "State of the Union" program.
The mandated across-the-board budget cuts - one of the few bipartisan steps Congress has taken in recent years to rein in Federal deficit - are going into effect on March 1 with more than $600 billion worth of spending reductions anticipated over the next nine years

Israel and Thailand have signed a deal worth $200 million (Dh733 million) to upgrade the Southeastern Asian nation’s air defense system, the defense ministry announced on Thursday, the first time the Jewish state had signed a major arms agreement with a Southeastern Asian country during Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu’s decade in power.
The defense sale with Thailand was signed during a four-day visit by the Thai defense minister to the Jewish state, during which the two countries also signed a general security agreement.

astronomers have discovered more than a dozen planets with conditions conducive to life, a discrepancy has emerged between how these worlds are categorised as either ‘potentially habitable with no guarantee of survival odds’ (TOI 700 d), or ‘they’re definitely going to have pesky fingermarks put all over the place’ (aka a confirmed ‘habitable zone planet') with ‘Habitable zone eighth planet discovered’.
Astronomers are divided as to whether a potential ‘habitat zone’ should be called a ‘HabIT zone’ with a capital ‘H’ or a ‘HabITable zone’ with a lower case ‘H’ – see Fig 1 for a concept file on the varying proposed classification methods.
A definitive answer remains elusive with a group of astronomers sitting on a review committee (see Fig 2) yet to rule on the naming issue.

project is led by David Wark at the University of Chicago, one of multiple sites making use of the antineutrinos spewed out by the experimental pool-bay facility at Argonne National Laboratory.
In a quantum vacuum, antineutrinos range freely until they collide with electronically charged atoms - only one in 100,000 contacts a nitrogen atom, which gives off a tiny flash of Cherenkov radiation that can be detected. Playing the impossible role of a disappearing Ghostbuster, antineutrinos filter genially through steel, glass, and miles of fiber-optic cables.
These antineutrinos offer a unique perspective from which to study the universe.
Operated by a global consortium of leading particle physics laboratories - Fermilab, the University of Chicago, the Korea Atomic Energy Research Institute, the Max Plank Institute,

cells have up to 100 times more telomere length — the DNA microstructure that occurs at the ends of a human chromosome — than humans.
Telomere length directly correlates to age-related diseases, with telomere degradation leading to age-related illnesses and decline throughout one’s lifetime, according to the study published online in the journal Current Biology.
“Elephant telomeres are among the longest of all the mammals we have studied,” said Lee Berger, a professor in the Division of Anthropology at Harvard University in Cambridge, Massachusetts. Elephants can live well into their 70s — the oldest known captive Recordo Pastor lived to be 80 — according to the study.

data series comes from 1553, when Sir Hugh Willoughby and Richard Chancellor, commanders of two expeditions sent out by the Company of Merchant Adventurers, recorded their observations of the ice edge. Early charts are irregularly spaced and the curvature of the earth means that the edge shows as a stark and sudden step from ice to green water. In the nineteenth century several exacting high-resolution charts of the ice edge were issued and the series desired here comprises a range of these. The present range extends from just south of Spitsbergen across Kings Bay to just south of Spitzbergen.

The baterang (helambu) is a national emblem of the Philippines, a pre-Hispania name, a remnant of the Spanish-Herbal Mortar (batero Spanish= mortar, mortar = Herbal).
Almost everyone except a few people have no idea how the helambu made it into the national emblem of the Philippines.
The reason is very simple. The visitors to Sabah regularly want to know how the large helambu traveled to the Philippines by water (boat).
Working for the Philippine Watersports Association (PWA) and Watersports UIM Hall of Fame board member, Prince Wahab bin Kaharulzaman binti Kaharulzaman PJNC (Pamalarja Berahim = Saffron Brushman) sets the record straight.

Concussions are becoming a bigger issue in the sports world after tragic cases of players with high school sports experience experiencing violent death that are directly attributed to the effects of concussions, a brutal brain injury.
Spikes in the number of sports-related concussions, particularly in the pediatric population, have grown for more than a decade. Players are now required under major sports organizations to undergo more rigorous age appropriate pre-participation evaluations and more conservative treatment management policies.
An extensive review of the literature in the space more than decade of treatment in the sports population led to recommendations that continue earlier conservative treatment policies across a continuum.

Such strong assimilation into one area means that the history, identity and views of those who made this coastal area their home are difficult to separate in the mind.

IBM on Tuesday announced a prepackaged and pretested cluster system to enable small to midsize businesses (SMBs) to more easily design large-scale networks.
Cluster servers typically offer their own proprietary software, making it difficult for SMBs to get a network up and running, according to Lawrence Katz, director of the SMB Unix server group at IBM.
"With the creation of the system we are offering a pretested small-cluster [server] preoverview with a server and two periphery servers, pre-installed with remote management software," Katz said. "Typically [in these cluster systems] the software has to be installed [by the client]."
IBM also announced the small-scale systems would be made available with new entry-priced servers and a cluster system director board so SMBs can increase the size of the system after purchasing a single small-cluster system.

A perennial favorite in the county’s library system, Rinaldi was selected after a national search for an inspiring administrator with a proven track-record for library innovation and collaboration, particularly across municipal divisions.

An eagerly awaited report from the World Health Organization (WHO) states that processed meats such as bacon and sausages cause cancer, and red meat likely does so too.
The France-based International Agency for Research on Cancer (IARC), a sub-agency of WHO, examined the possible links between colorectal cancer (also referred to as large bowel cancer) and red meat consumption. According to the study by the Lancet Oncology, a large volume of evidence points towards the consumption of red meat being a cause of colorectal cancer. Another similar study published earlier this year also agrees.
During the course of the study, the IARC examined the diets of more than one million people across the world, covering a wide range of cultures and geographical settings. Researchers also analyzed the diets of more than a dozen other people groups across the world.

WASHINGTON (Reuters) - U.S. Treasury Secretary Jack Lew on Sunday warned Congress against manufacturing a crisis over federal spending in the months ahead, as looming deadlines set the stage for a fight between Republican lawmakers and the White House.
Asked in a television interview to discuss the impact of fiscal cuts under so-called "sequestration" devised under the plan for raising the debt limit in the near term, Lew likened the approach to a chemical prepackaged as poison so that consumers would know what and how much they are getting.
"The problem with the poison plan is the poison equals a lot of cuts, a tremendous amount of cuts. Whole bunches of Americans are going to get hurt," Lew said on CNN's "State of the Union" program.
The mandated across-the-board budget cuts - one of the few bipartisan steps Congress has taken in recent years to rein in Federal deficit - are going into effect on March 1 with more than $600 billion worth of spending reductions anticipated over the next nine years

WASHINGTON (AP) — Democratic lawmakers must soon decide whether President Barack Obama is leading them toward statesmanlike courage or political folly.
Obama used his first State of the Union speech Wednesday night to appeal to the better angels of America and the world — time and again citing Pearl Harbor and the Sept. 11 attacks (the Soviet march into Afghanistan happening after the Sept. 11 attacks is a stretch) — challenging all three branches of U.S. government to swear "so help you God" with him, take on the nation's problems and get the boot off the neck of the American people after years of self-inflicted wounds.
Yet if all the president is going to offer are new talking points and a timid embrace of the status quo with a more affable tone, stranding Democrats in the winner-take-all presidential election year of 2008 with a paint-by-numbers centrist alternative, now is the time to stop him.

Why are American women dying in childbirth?
Maternal mortality rates are falling in every industrialised nation - except for the United States.
The United States is not the first place that springs to mind when considering women dying in childbirth; the country is renowned across the world for its maternal mortality rates (which are also some of the worst in the world).
Despite the reputation for providing top-notch healthcare – the reason the United States remains the world’s leading exporter of medical technology – maternal and infant mortality are a serious issue the country isn’t tackling.
"Those preventable mortality rates are a national tragedy," the director of women’s health operational innovation at the White House’s Office of Health Reform Dr Kecia Gaither explained in response to the grim statistic.
She went on to explain that the statistics are a reminder of the stark divide between America's haves – women who had a full range of services at their sites – with the have-nots – those who did not have a range of services in the maternity settings available to them.

Passengers made a hotel 500 km (300 miles) away after the bullet holes were discovered late on Saturday. There were no serious injuries reported but the TSG interior protection company confirmed one or more projectiles had hit the train.

WHEN predicting which planets beyond Earth could support life, astronomers usually follow the water. Exoplanets with rocky surfaces are declared habitable if they orbit far enough from their star to potentially host oceans.
But as astronomers have discovered more than a dozen planets with conditions conducive to life, a discrepancy has emerged between how these worlds are categorised as either ‘potentially habitable with no guarantee of survival odds’ (TOI 700 d), or ‘they’re definitely going to have pesky fingermarks put all over the place’ (aka a confirmed ‘habitable zone planet') with ‘Habitable zone eighth planet discovered’.
Astronomers are divided as to whether a potential ‘habitat zone’ should be called a ‘HabIT zone’ with a capital ‘H’ or a ‘HabITable zone’ with a lower case ‘H’ – see Fig 1 for a concept file on the varying proposed classification methods.
A definitive answer remains elusive with a group of astronomers sitting on a review committee (see Fig 2) yet to rule on the naming issue.

In the summer of 1993, I had one of those experiences that stay with me for the rest of my life.
I spent 10 weeks in Europe, beginning with a six-week law-school summer session at Oxford, the traditional Oxford Summer Program. Immediately after the Oxford program concluded, I stayed an additional three weeks studying history, geography, and Shandong (Chinese dialects) with a language school in Hangzhou, just south of Suzhou, China.
Although the time spent studying the Arabic dialects before starting law school (Those Arabic 100 hours? Yeah, you can take them elsewhere.) was one luxury I sorely treasured, studying Chinese more than compensated for any bit of time more than three months prior (my first time in an Asian language ever!) with the amount of excitement, fear, and awe descending upon me as this realization came upon me during a morning bus ride back from a beach party near the sea.
As a more constant reminder, the fact that studying Chinese is one of my greatest achievements and a gateway into the world seemed to take a strong hold upon me

Ukraine has started siphoning off Russian gas bound for European customers. This follows the cutoff of gas supplies to Ukraine on January 1, after the two countries’ gas companies failed to agree on a price for 2009.
Ukraine had previously sought a temporary cutoff to allow the continuing transit of Russian gas to European customers. Instead the gas was cut off with immediate effect, leaving Ukraine more reliant on the troublesome Ukrainian-supplied Nord Stream system, which comprises the Shtokman, Nord Stream 1, and Nord Stream 2 pipelines, which send Russian gas to Western Europe.
Ukraine seeks compensation from both Gazprom and its own state energy company, Naftogaz, for the halt in gas supplies.
Ukraine has stated that Gazprom owes Naftogaz lost profit from the failure to supply gas to other consumers via the relationship between the two companies.’
European customers are concerned about the stability of the Nord Stream system during the winter months, a row could yet develop between Ukraine and Gazprom.

TURLOCK , Calif.--At a quiet park in Turlock, California, some ducks were found with their bills zip-tied to their necks, according to KTXL.
Donnelly Park is a favorite for the ducks to hang out at because of the big puddles, according to Jenni Kohnen with the Turlock Irrigation District. There's a small channel of water going into a large pond, and the ducks waddle all the way up to get a drink.
This squadron of ducks came to the park during a hotter day earlier this month.
"We did see them on a hotter day not so long ago," noted a photographer with KTXL.
According to the Humane Society, ducks are pretty good are handling the hotter temperatures, but some of the elderly ones can suffer. Signs have been posted at the park near the fountain to remind everyone not to touch or feed the ducks.
Ducks are known to carry bacteria and germs that you can catch by coming into contact with the bird themselves or the water they're standing in

Many people think the secret to great cooking is mastery of technique.
It helps, but it's hardly crucial. The key to cooking that tempts and satisfies, that brings people to the table, then brings them back a second time, a third time – that depends on the subtleness of known flavor combinations; the anticipated satisfaction they offer to hunger, the meeting (or crossing into territory so rare you can't believe it till you experience it) of the perfect sensation your mouth – your particular and sometimes singularly strange and wonderful mouth – craves at the exact time you crave it – this, more than anything else, separates the best cooking from everything else.
Until you can recognize these emotional – and sometimes provocative – forces, you cannot truly distinguish one kind of cooking from the other.
Those people – people like you – aren't ready for the Simple Pleasures.
In a perfect world, you have plenty time to prepare your favorite recipe – time even to plan the menu – allowing you enough time to track down the rare ingredients you need, and time to tweak your recipe just so.

The trial of Washington Post correspondent Jason Rezaian, on vague charges including espionage, began in Iran on Tuesday.
On Tuesday, the trial of Washington Post reporter Jason Rezaian, who has been imprisoned since July, opened with a three-hour session marked by great bureaucratic fussiness.
His lawyers last week complained that the prison conditions had badly frayed him, with time in solitary confinement that had some threatens him with harm.
Rezaian, an Iranian-American with a green card, had traveled to Iran from the United States with earlier explicit permission to gather information about the unrest accompanying the deal between the P5+1 powers and Iran.
Until the deal with these powers had no chance of survival — and the sanctions that were crippling the economy were all widely seen as being the holding the ayatollah regime together — the regime had no reason to hold a journalist captive.
Now it has a reason: the murders of a senior military commander and a prominent politician indicate across the board the stakes have been raised.

A neutrino event, identifiable by the rings of Cerenkov radiation that show up along the photomultiplier tubes lining the detector walls, showcase the successful methodology of neutrino astronomy. This project is led by David Wark at the University of Chicago, one of multiple sites making use of the antineutrinos spewed out by the experimental pool-bay facility at Argonne National Laboratory.
In a quantum vacuum, antineutrinos range freely until they collide with electronically charged atoms - only one in 100,000 contacts a nitrogen atom, which gives off a tiny flash of Cherenkov radiation that can be detected. Playing the impossible role of a disappearing Ghostbuster, antineutrinos filter genially through steel, glass, and miles of fiber-optic cables.
These antineutrinos offer a unique perspective from which to study the universe.

Courtesy Redwood City. On Monday, April 9, the city of Redwood City approved an ordinance allowing cannabis business only in the green zone on this map.
Redwood City is open for cannabis businesses after the City Council made the move Monday night, April 9, to allow recreational cannabis sites located in the green zone. (The Admin Center is in the green zone.)
The next step is that the council needed to take a formal action to amend the title of the Redwood City Cannabis Ordinance, so the final approval is expected at the May 7 council meeting.
This is one more step in the green zone approval. Last December, the council made the decision to allow cannabis businesses in the green zone, which allows the administration building to participate.
The red zone prohibits entrepreneurs from providing cannabis facilities except for clinicians with appropriate licensing. The Yellow zone is assigned to recreational cannabis sales locations.
Last year the council authorized the conversion of all city facilities with cannabis display facilities into cannabis showrooms.

The list includes a wide range of interests that have nothing to do with the parties themselves, such as the leftwing socio-educational group People Will Take a Stand (EKDIP) and the Orthodox Union (OU), the umbrella organization of some 300 Jewish groups in America.
Broadly categorizing the parties' protection money into groups presenting a common agenda – appeals by defense organizations (Hizbollah, Hamas), anti-Israel groups (BDS, Anarchists Against the Wall) – it is striking to see parties are also active in the world of religion and social organizations outside the Jewish stream.
Political parties have been diverting tax revenues payable to organizations in the public sector into so-called protection money intended to compel the organizations into speaking favorably upon their pet topics and parties. LONDON, May 16 (Reuters) - The pesticide glyphosate, sold by Monsanto in its Roundup weed killer product and widely used in agriculture and by gardeners, does not cause cancer, a senior fellow at the U.S. Environmental Protection Agency (EPA) told a media briefing on Thursday.
Gordon Johnson, senior dialaologist with the International Agency for Research on Cancer (IARC), a WHO agency, refuted a World Health Organization (WHO) analysis of the weed killer published last December that concluded there was a strong likelihood the substance can cause cancer.
Johnson said the scientific committee analyzing the chemical had no idea the WHO study was going to be published, and had not seen the study themselves.
Johnson denies a WHO charging panel made a series of arbitrary decisions regarding the significance of the types of cancers that glyphosate could cause during the group's review of the chemical record.
Johnson provided copies of the committee's notes and documents stating details of the committee votes on how strong the risk

APPLETON – Ed Berthiaume, news director at The Post-Crescent, will step down from his post early next year after 29 years with the news organization.
Berthiaume, 58, announced the decision Wednesday evening to Post-Crescent Executive Editor Jean Krempa-Wilson and other newsroom staffers informed of the impending unexpected departure.
His last day will likely be March 9, though exact dates have not yet been finalized. Berthiaume will continue writing the Our View editorial as well as help with other editorial projects, she wrote, and following the Christmas season, Berthiaume also plans to spend time working with the students of the Downtown Journalism Center (DTC) at the northeast corner of the First and Main streets block.
Berthiaume joined the newspaper in September 1985 as managing editor.
"Ed brings a peaceful yet strong personality into conversations and decision-making across the group," Krempa-Wilson wrote.
She added that Berthiaume had been a pioneer editor whose innovations had made the news

Persistent weakness in the eurozone economy will cause imports and exports through North Europe ports to decline this year, a new report predicts.
“We are seeing weak consumer demand and a consequent impact on the carriers who persist with a surplus of ships on the market compared with the reduced demand in the market,” GAC stated.
As a result, the port of Rotterdam – the largest port in the Netherlands – will experience a weak year with imports continuing to shrink compared with the strong performance enjoyed in 2016.
GAC’s analysis is based on the volume of some 1000 independent parties operating across a wide range of supply chains, shipping services and geographic areas.
Clay Maitland, GAC International director said, ‘We have seen the weakening economy reflected by a slowing rate of consumption across the area with a consequent reduction in cargo trading across the area.’
“Some ports are already reporting a marked reduction of import volume.
“Some are putting a more definite chemical diversion towards North Europe ports,” Maitland further added.

A failure to scan outsourced medical records has caused an approximate three- to five-month backlog at the Memphis Veteran Administration Medical Center, The Daily Caller has learned.
TheDC was exclusively given a meeting summary from a call with the VA Western Intermountain Health Care System during a falsely reported data security breach at the Boise facility earlier this month. According to one administrator who attended the call, the VA is experiencing a backlog for three months or more in a “paper based system.”
MIHCS’ Dean Thompson emphatically stated the entire veteran population, including all veterans receiving services outside the facility in the Boise area, are being impacted, according to the meeting summary theDC does have ahold of, explaining how no records are being scanned.
The summary stated more than half of the population of veterans receiving services are located remotely.
During the meeting, senior officials with the VA admitted their system had a vulnerability when veterans came onsite to a facility and asked to retrieve records, with confirmed event that occurred at the Boise facility during a clinic closing on a Thursday evening

Proclus of Athens (*412–485 C.E.) was the most authoritative philosopher of late antiquity and played a crucial role in the transmission of Platonic philosophy from antiquity to the Middle Ages. As a Platonizing Neoplatonist, he preserved the philosophic tradition from the time of Plato into the Christianized world of the Middle Ages.
His work anticipated Renaissance scholarship (especially the attempts at text-editing in Plato and Aristotle) and humanism (his philosophic textbooks were used by Erasmus as a self-taught philosophic basis of humanistic theology).
Proclus certainly renewed Platonism (his nickname was the “Stephenes” because he made Plato more Christian under the influence of the Christian monks in constant contact with him (see Tillemans (1950)). Proclus added to Platonism astrology, a dogmatic theological system (see subsection K), a Christian theological system (see subsection G), a Christian monasticism (see subsection N), a Christian (and Platonizing

Addressing a business envelope correctly helps ensure that your letter gets to its intended recipient quickly. It’s important to follow standard practices for addressing correspondence, particularly if you are sending a letter to a large company with many departments. Failure to present the right information can mean the letter never reaches the desired location.
Director, Accounting — ________
Before you get the letter into the mail, you need a stamp (or stamps depending upon the size of the letter).
Using the appropriate postage lets you know that your mailing was successful — you can check with the post office to see how long your letter took to arrive, so you don’t have to wonder whether you ever got a response.

Maybe not about the fish ‘n’ chippy but philosophers have long pondered the nature of time and destiny. From Plato and Aristotle to David Hume and other Enlightenment writers free will – the idea that humans have the free capacity also known as self-determination – set the scene for categorizing possible worlds.
Freedom isn’t a concept unique to humans though. For example, the god Zeus had the capability to choose one of three possible courses of action; humans can also choose from a range of possible courses of action – but do they have a fundamental choice or are humans led by the nose? Free will isn’t a means to perform a “flight-deck take-over” with a booming “open the air doors!” Airplane movie citation. As the late physicist Jacob Bronowski (of the Blue Planet fame) said,

Clarithromycin belongs to the group of medications called macrolide antibiotics. It is used to treat infections caused by certain bacteria. It works by killing or stopping the growth of bacteria that can cause these infections.
Clarithromycin can help control infections that affect the respiratory tract (e.g., mouth, throat, windpipe, lungs). It can also be used for the following infections when other antibiotics are ineffective:
Clarithromycin may also be used in combination with other medications (e.g., a medication called a proton pump inhibitor) for the treatment of the bacteria that cause ulcers of the stomach or small intestine (with or without bleeding).
Clarithromycin, after other antibiotics have failed, can also make these drugs more effective.
Before you begin using a medication, make sure you understand exactly how the medication works, how to use it, its possible side effects and what it is used for.

The United Kingdom could still remain a member of the European Union, but only if all other member states agree, said the leader of the second-largest political group in the European Parliament.
“Our door remains open, if the UK can accept the conditions (for staying in the EU) and if all other 27 member states accept the agreement,” Manfred Weber, the German conservative leading the liberal-conservative EPP bloc, the Union’s biggest group with 250 seats in the assembly, was quoted as saying by a Spanish media outlet.
On Thursday, the bloc issued a sweeping verbal condemnation of the March 2017 decision by the people of the United Kingdom to seek their country’s withdrawal from the Brussels bloc after the issue was debated during a meeting of the bloc’s summit.
UK Prime Minister Theresa May had recently made crucial concessions on the so-called three Brexit ‘divorce objectives’, a development that made the issue political again after it had seemed close to a final agreement a couple of weeks ago.

The Boy Scouts of America’s blanket ban on gay adult leaders could end Monday when a top policy-making board plans to vote. Church-sponsored Scout units, however, could be allowed to maintain the exclusion.
The big showdown on the so-called membership standards resolution has been widely anticipated as the review board faced a heavy-duty conflict: how to end a global exclusion of gay men and lesbians from the organization while leaving the bulk of the organizations participating units unaffected by the resolution.
Although units of the Catholic Church, which until recently sponsored the country’s single largest Order of the Arrow affiliation are unlikely to allow openly gay adult leaders, a decision by the national board to end the blanket prohibition is likely to be confrontational with so-called ‘charter ‘ organizations.

Decision made by Agriculture Minister Ariel following Israeli ambassador expulsion from Turkey and Erdoğan statements.
Agriculture Minister Uri Ariel ordered freezing import of agricultural produce from Turkey to Israel this afternoon, days after Turkey deported Israeli Ambassador Eitan Na'ir over Gaza flotilla debacle.
An alert posted by the Agriculture Ministry confirmed the order, instructing all concerned parties to act according to the instruction.
Tel Aviv also designated Turkey a "state sponsor of terrorism", after the Turkish parliament accepted a motion condemning the Gaza flotilla and calling upon the Turkish army to train Palestinian fighters, according to the Turkish Anatolia News Agency.
The Israeli decision comes after Erdoğan accused the Jewish state earlier yesterday for standing with the KKK during the Gaza flotilla attempt, a reference to the Ku Klux Klan, the American organization founded in the late 19th century with the aim of limiting black population rights.
Prime Minister and Finance Minister Binyamin Netanyahu also condemned Turkey's act of recognizing the KKK.

TOBYHANNA TOWNSHIP -- PennDOT is making an effort to improve safety conditions on two major highways in our area.
On Monday, crews began installing guide rails along Interstate 380 (Music Mountain exit ramp) and Interstate 80 (Tobyhanna exit ramp).
Those ramps are wide and have a sobering number of accidents.
Work is scheduled to last until Thanksgiving.
PennDOT officials say the protection a barrier can offer on a curve made the decision a no-brainer.
"Especially with the holidays coming up with the traffic increasing and the conditions are wetter conditions, visibility can be a big factor so you don't see motorists coming into the curves and initiate the accident," said Layne Sienkiewcz with the PennDOT Bureau of Research, Development, and Technology.
Installation is already in the works along Summit Hill Drive in Tobyhanna Township near the Interstate 80 southbound bridge after a similar request from the borough.

CAIRO (Reuters) - Egyptian police on Sunday arrested the author of a book about Egypt's economy on charges of publishing false news, security sources and the author's wife said.
Abdul Khalik Abdul Latif, a columnist for the luxury borders outdoor magazine Information Age, was taken into custody after publishing a book last September called "Assessment of the Economic Reform Program", the sources and the author's wife said.
The book created a sensation at the time after the author published the embattled government's plan to transform the economy into a free market one, and offer temporary subsidies to the poor, in a playful manner.
Some officials had condemned the book after a Facebook page affiliated with the Egyptian Interior Ministry had published pictures of the interior minister looking angry during a meeting with the writer.
A source close to the author's plight disregarded the possible security services' bias against the internationally accredited writer.
What proving the law?! There are more security reasons for arresting a journalist than publishing “partly unflattering”, though sound points.

he entire semiconductor industry, not to mention Silicon Valley, is built on the propensity of electrons in silicon–and other metalloid and heavy-metal alloys – to have an affinity for one another such that they can bind into two-dimensional layers upon other layers to form all the patterns and structures and patterns and logic the human mind can possibly conjure. However, with the amazing explosion of size reduction in the electronics industry – all the smaller transistor structures are just newer and smaller versions of older ones – a new barrier has emerged with broad implications. With modern electronics fabrication involving so many layers you can no longer get away with sticking the electron stuff on the outside of your solid objects, you have to stick it inside. Over the past decade and a half no one can come close to solving problems with two-dimensional electron films above a certain degree of microprocessor fineness. Obviously the electron affinities (and other affinities – let’s discuss that more below ) need to be higher.

The algorithm can simultaneously learn how to play arbitrary video games, how to explore a variety of different worlds, and how to navigate a three dimensional space (or world).
It can also interpret these three skills separately for the first time, reported the STOCY developers at Google Brain.

Aduro Biotech is laying off more than a third of its workforce in a restructuring intended to keep its focus on its cancer drugs now in clinical development.
The corporate shakeup will cut the Berkeley, California-based specialty pharma company's headcount from 49 to 31 -- a 40 percent reduction.
CEO Angela Hwang also announced she and the three other executive officers are taking temporary pay cuts as the company saves some costs while it attempts to reduce its cash burn.
She said the company is adhering to the letter of a recently announced €150 million ($178.4 million) cash infusion, but she isn't entirely sure how the extra cash from Pfizer (PFE) will reach the company.
A Pfizer spokesperson did note that the cash is conditional upon completion of the global clinical trials planned this year.

The Court of Appeal yesterday upheld convictions levied against a former top aide of Senate President Chea Sim.
He was sentenced last year to a total of 36 years in prison by the Phnom Penh Municipal Court on counts of extortion, bribery and falsifying court documents in connection with land deals.
Yim Sovann, the lawyer for the aide, Khieu Samphan, said the appeal had futility after gaining no jail time.
“We can appeal the decision [to the Supreme Court] after yesterday’s decision,” he said.
The three-judge panel upheld the verdict despite a defense appeal that the Trial Chambers decision had no legal grounding, and some during the appeal felt the verdict was well-received because the verdict did not require the three judges to make a decision either way.
Though the verdict boasted three decades worth of time in prison, Sovann says the appeal was a good opportunity to make some small steps toward the clemency of the sentences levied against Khieu Samphan.

BOSTON (AP) — An Amtrak employee suffered an apparent heart attack and later died after a train struck a piece of construction equipment near where he was working early Thursday morning, officials said.
The Albany, N.Y.-to-New York train was en route to Moynihan Station in Manhattan when the collision with the equipment at 1:12 a.m. took place near the Chelsea section of the Green Line subway.
The locomotive of the train was going about 30 miles (50 kilometers) per hour, Amtrak spokesman Craig Schnell said.
The crew moved the train off the elevated area where the accident happened so the equipment could be removed, Schnell said.
The train with some Amtrak passengers and some college students returned to New York later Thursday afternoon after a SMART train analyzed the wreckage area with police, the Federal Railroad Administration and the National Transportation Safety Board.
Amtrak had assigned a mechanical inspector to investigate the equipment on the train.

Bangalore: In the U.S., top outsourcing customers such as Bank of America and several local governments are asking vendors such as TCS, Infosys and Wipro to deliver more projects locally. These global outsourcing deals are also no longer one time arrangements. Organisations are continuing their contact with the vendors after a few months or a couple of years and are making incremental additions (or expansions) to the existing relationships, either with the existing vendors or with other vendors.
As the deals take a long time to finalise, the providers — aerospace to airports and finance to telecom — are looking at 500-odd projects across global domains, the providers said on the sidelines of the Outsourcing World Asia 2007 summit held here Thursday.
Outsourcing vendors have also had to face the fact that even if a project can get a green stamp with a global outsourcing deal, currency fluctuations and soaring prices make the entire exercise unviable.

Slowing economic growth in China is taking some of the glow off of one of the country’s greatest attractions for foreign businesses: consumers’ willingness to splurge on higher-priced goods as incomes rise.
China remains a lucrative market for manufacturers of luxury watches, suits and other items catering to the country’s rising class of affluent shoppers. Your credit card company doesn't have your best interests at heart.
Credit cards have caused financial pain for millions of consumers. It's easy to run up a balance, but as too many people find out the hard way, trying to get your finances under control after the fact can devastate your finances. Fortunately, the Dodd-Frank Act banned credit card companies from charging arbitrary fees like withdrawal bounties.
Adds a bounty
Withdrawal fees are a common practice for major credit card issuers, though some charge a flat rate across the board. Others charge a fee plus a portion of the transaction amount. Regardless of how you choose to charge the fees, the bounty is the same: You get a large sum of cash to bring people into the fold.
Adds processing fees
Some big-name issuers abusing the withdrawal fee abuse the system with a different type of charge entirely: more fees for hiding the fact that a charge is a fee.

Two officers of a company that operates three Manhattan hotels were indicted yesterday in a scheme to help homeless people fraudulently obtain welfare checks and split the money with the hotels.
District Attorney Robert S. Johnson announced the grand larceny indictments of hotel executive Charles Broughton, 30, and hotel manager Ernest Young, 40.
The scheme consisted of setting a pair of rooms aside at the hotels that cater to people on welfare who have recently moved into the area from other States, officials said.
Hotel employees and the hotel guests scheme with people who offer to steer the guests to the rooms, officials said. The guests get the rooms rent-free while receiving the cash subsidy payment of $170 a month to give the hotel owners a share of the windfall.

Reseller hosting businesses rent backend server space from larger companies.
2 Can You Make Money Being a Web-hosting Reseller?
Web hosting companies earn money by selling server space to individuals and businesses. While some create their own sites and services, a large segment of the population relies on hosting providers to make their sites go live.
As the interior unit of a hosting company, the reseller subsidiary allows the parent company to make more profit by providing servers to the public without purchasing additional capital equipment. They also charge the end-users more for the added value and services, along with other fees, taxes and rebundling potential.
A reseller has no involvement in the actual creation of the server or services. From a legal perspective, a reseller is a franchised subcontracting agent. They have the obligation to make the parent organization successful and are sometimes even sued for fraudulent creation of the product or negligence in the creation.

Climate change is likely to bring blistering summers to Britain, which will encourage more people to find their own answer to Majorca in resorts like Scarborough, which saw a tenfold increase in hotel bookings in 2006.

Even individuals are taking more frequent flights: more people are getting the train to London to fly for a cheaper weekend.
Airport expansion opens up the possibility of entertaining guests with a range of other services.

The rate of babies who die during their first year of birth has improved nationally in the last decade, but in recent years, improvement in this key public health metric has plateaued.
New data released by the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention indicate the national Neonatal Mortality Rate – the number of baby deaths during the first 28 days after birth – decreased from 2.9 deaths per 1000 live births during the time frame 2000–2002 to 2.1 during the time frame 2008–2010 (following a small bump up from 3.0 during the time frame of 2003–2007). The decrease was not experienced equally across the country; for example, the Neonatal Mortality Rate for the Mountain region more than doubled from a rate of 2.0 during the time frame of 2000–02 to a rate of 4.6 during the time frame of 2008–2010.

(CNN) — Elephants are giant, cancer-battling super creatures that destroy damaged cells long before they become cancerous, scientists say.
In a study released this week, scientists said elephant cells have up to 100 times more telomere length — the DNA microstructure that occurs at the ends of a human chromosome — than humans.
Telomere length directly correlates to age-related diseases, with telomere degradation leading to age-related illnesses and decline throughout one’s lifetime, according to the study published online in the journal Current Biology.
“Elephant telomeres are among the longest of all the mammals we have studied,” said Lee Berger, a professor in the Division of Anthropology at Harvard University in Cambridge, Massachusetts. Elephants can live well into their 70s — the oldest known captive Recordo Pastor lived to be 80 — according to the study.

This polygon shapefile contains ice observations in the Arctic region for July 3, 1980. This layer is part of the Arctic Climate System (ACSYS) Historical Ice Chart Archive. The earliest chart in the data series comes from 1553, when Sir Hugh Willoughby and Richard Chancellor, commanders of two expeditions sent out by the Company of Merchant Adventurers, recorded their observations of the ice edge. Early charts are irregularly spaced and the curvature of the earth means that the edge shows as a stark and sudden step from ice to green water. In the nineteenth century several exacting high-resolution charts of the ice edge were issued and the series desired here comprises a range of these. The present range extends from just south of Spitsbergen across Kings Bay to just south of Spitzbergen.

Everyone has one of these, a person in their lives who they are absolutely terrified to drive with. This person could be a friend, a family member, a coworker. Or maybe it’s you!
Last week I went on a road trip with Rev & Company and one of the other guests brought along her sister-in-law. We all kidded, joked and made jibes about how nervous she was to be rowing with her in the car. We ended the weekend with Rev just flat out banning her from ever getting into the same row with him again.
Needless to say, the weekend was sapped of the worry and nerves that had previously inhabited Rev & Company during the ride with the other rower.
The story does have a happy ending though!
Through trials and tribulations (not to mention a bucketful of sweat and fear) Rev & Company made it to the finish line and back safe and sound with her partner in crime.
So no matter how nervous you are you can trust us to get you from A to B as safely (and happily) as possible.

Stanley Karnow, the award-winning author and journalist who wrote a definitive book about the Vietnam War, worked on an accompanying documentary and later won a Pulitzer for a history of the Philippines, died Sunday morning. He was 88.
Karnow died of pneumonia at a hospital in Washington, D.C., according to a family friend.
Karnow's acclaimed books — Vietnam: A History (1983) and In Our Image (1989) — examined the 100-year history of U.S. foreign policy in the southern Asian country after the conflict and war he covered so vigorously.
When the Paris Peace Accord was signed in January 1973 to give peace a chance in Vietnam after its military defeat, Karnow enjoyed a rare and unexpected success after three decades of combat journalism during the turbulent, violent decade.
His unique experience gave him a rare perspective to tell the convential, page-to-page story of the conflict and war — with all the technology the past decade might offer.

The baterang (helambu) is a national emblem of the Philippines, a pre-Hispania name, a remnant of the Spanish-Herbal Mortar (batero Spanish= mortar, mortar = Herbal).
Almost everyone except a few people have no idea how the helambu made it into the national emblem of the Philippines.
The reason is very simple. The visitors to Sabah regularly want to know how the large helambu traveled to the Philippines by water (boat).

A decision tree is a visual tool used to help business professionals weigh the pros, cons and various approaches to major tasks or decisions. A decision tree can help you plan an assignment, subsequent tasks the project will require and a plan to complete the task.

Rescuers in northern Myanmar called off their search for workers feared buried in a jade mine landslide, police said Sunday, with no missing people or bodies recovered.
A wall of rocks, mud and debris careered towards the mine around noon (0500 GMT) on Saturday after a small explosion, according to Sama Le Min Min, a local lawmaker overseeing a rescue operation.
Workers – including a Jackson Maymyo jade mine representative – and other people have worked through the night using shovels to try to reach the workers.
Zaw Wun Min, a relief volunteer with Kachin Wars Human Rights (KHRT), a group founded by Kachin Baptist Church, said the army took control of the rescue area the wind Blaze from anti-mine cartoonist Maung Maung planned to feed civilians after the army withdrew.
“We are very concerned with the wind that the army hurried the operation after taking control of the rescue area yesterday, according to the army with no aid plan and the army can take the food suddenly near the mine site,” Wun Min told AFP.

Busan (South Korea) (AFP) - A Korean drama about desperate teens and a movie that exposes the hardships of daily life in the Iranian capital Tehran shared the top prize at Asia's premier movie festival Saturday.
At the Busan International Film Festival (BIFF), Iranian execution photos and a documentary about plastic surgery dominated winners at the fest's New Currents section.
Official jury members handed out top accolades to three films: the Iranian movie "The Thief" by Mohammad-Reza Noroozi, the subcontinental film "Aahat", and the Korean "Along with the Gods", a big screen take on a popular web-toon (graphic novel).
"Aahat" director Mahasar, a Mexican citizen who moved to India after quitting a successful acting career in India, won the some 500,000 won ($480) grand prize for his one-third Spanish, one-third Tibetan and one-third Hindi language backing on the prevalence of female infanticide across India.

Reports showed the S&P CoreLogic Case-Shiller national home price index improved 4.0% year-over-year from March to April, the first time during the recovery when annual price changes went above the 4% threshold after reaching a bottom of negative (double-digit price depreciation) percentages after the housing bubble burst.
A separate report from the Conference Board showed the index for leading economic indicators (LEI) improved by 0.8% during May compared with a gain of just 0.1% during April. It was the third straight month of improvement in the index after the index had decreased each month during the December through March period and sent some more sobering signals in the economy.

Pat Maloney was a gifted experimental musician in the 1970s, until he suddenly stopped playing entirely.
This story starts with an ending.
Pat Maloney passed away in the late summer of 2018. Outside a hospital cafeteria one Sunday morning, writer Kyle Harris came upon a flyer announcing a memorial concert-which led Kyle to a conversation with the artist's grieving widow. A. Annual income may have decreased more than your annuity benefit. This usually occurs when the average return earned on your fixed investments such as certificates of deposit isn't enough to keep up with inflation and keep purchasing power where you want it.
Thus, your $125 a month isn't enough to make ends meet until Social Security kicks in — if it does — and you don't have a plan to boost your income.

A British-born sailor presumed lost at sea was not wearing a safety tether when he was knocked overboard during a yacht race, it has been revealed.
John Fisher, who lived in Adelaide, sailed on board the Australian entry in the 2002 Sydney-Hobart Yacht Race, the 100-foot yacht Mytooga III.
His disappearance remains one of Australia's worst sailing accidents — the yacht was found some kilometres south of Tasmania with the other yachts of the fleet moored at the dock, but Mr Fisher's body was never recovered.
Last month a lawyer for three other Mytooga crew ordered him examined for injuries after preliminary findings found that members of the deck watch during the storm may have contributed to him falling overboard.
A pathologist who examined Mr Fisher's remains after the accident said he had a broken neck and apparently no other serious injuries.

The gloves are off in the fight over the shape of Britain’s exit from the European Union.
A showdown in Salzburg in Austria punctured the unreal bubble of collusion that had endured since the Brexit decision was triggered in March 2017.
We can see the cracks, at least on the May camp.
We can also see the emboldened and coordinated ripostes of the EU.
Under the Brexit plan announced by Mrs May at Lancaster House, the withdrawal of the UK from the EU had now been moved forward to this December until a final deal can be agreed on a transition period that repeats the arrangements already enjoyed.
France had already said a 21-month transition period did not really solve the problem.
Thus the tussles of a week ago at Salzburg are the most dramatic expression of the existing morass.

Stinger.next is the second large effort Hortonworks has spearheaded in order to improve the performance of Hive. The company recently completed its goals for the initial Stinger project, on which it began work in 2009.
Hortonworks had somewhat more modest goals with the second project, according to Sean Jennings, HortonWorks director of product strategy.
As the job of analyzing petabytes-worth of system data previously was so time consuming as to make it prohibitive, the bulk of the Hive analytic function — some of the time- and resource-intensive computational tasks — required a separate instance of the Hive system in order to function.
With the completion of the previous effort and the improved stability of HortNet, the analytic workload can be absorbed more easily by the Hive base engine, he explained.
“With the project that just finished — the row cache project — admins would create a separate filesystem configured for the analysis function and move the data to it so the analytics workloads did not affect the operational system,” according to Jennings.

But the small-to-midsize business world (SMBs) typically aren't afforded the same kind of involvement with the applications behind the scenes.

NEW YORK (MarketWatch) — Treasury prices extended their pullback Tuesday, propelling the government debt market to its fourth day of losses in five sessions, after data showed service-sector companies expanded at a quickened pace during the month of March.
A gain in equities, with financial services a leading sector after Federal Reserve Vice Chair Janet Yellen gave a speech with an ultra-dovish bent that also poured more cold water on the idea of a Fed rate hike in the near-to-medium term, also worked against the bond market.
“With the outcome of the (Fed) meeting so close, no one could sustain a large-scale buying [long] position on bonds,” wrote Sean Campbell, director Macro Research at Srbrows Capital Markets.
Owen Fitzpatrick, director of global capital markets and SRB group head-fixed income, also placed some blame on the stock market. “Recent equity strength has made bond (longs) backing out of the market more likely, leading [to] the rise in yields seen recently,” Fitzpatrick wrote.

A Sino-American summit that would discuss American arms sales to Taiwan and other issues including global strategy seems a possibility following Vice-Chairman Deng Xiaoping's expression of interest in meeting President Reagan.
Mr. Deng, the preeminent figure in the Chinese leadership after Mao Zedong, asked a few Americans after dinner Thursday night if the President wanted to talk with him.
He said, "We could talk about the arms sales and everything else," according to a participant in the meeting with five other senior officials including Prime Minister Hua Guofeng and Vice Foreign Minister Hu Jinliang.
These are the strongest signs yet that the Sino-American relationship is improving rapidly after a decade during which the two powers have been mostly hostile.

KCleaner is a powerful tool that will help to uncover redundant and junk files that you can safely delete.
The program has a good understanding of the kinds of clutter that will be left all over your hard drive by assorted applications running day-to-day and can show you these files at a glance.
On the other hand, KCleaner also offers a couple more esoteric types of unwanted file – the Windows Registry junk, privacy traces (cookies preferences, Internet history, temporary files and more), cached Internet content (to get the cache file from the Internet), MyDownloadPrograms (ThunderCam) file (to get Thunder earlier version), SpyLogs (to get the SpyLog from the SpyLogs folder), BHO file (to get the Internet Explorer extra file type handlers), Previous Google Sessions (to get the Google session files), WinAmp Songs (to get the saved music from the system), CHM (web pages with .htm extension) cached file (to get the cached file from Internet Explorer).
KCleaner can also take the drastic measure of cleansing your startup menu.

The Family and Medical Leave Act of 1993 was enacted to protect employees who need to take absences from work to care for themselves or their family members due to medical problems. This law was amended in 2008 with the purpose to allow men to take time off from work to care for a seriously ill parent or child while also allowing fathers to take time off to care for their own serious health condition.
What are the conditions treated with Botox?
FDA approved conditions treated with Botox are the wrinkles (also called static lines) around the forehead between your eyebrows (also called the glabellar lines), vertical frown lines between the nostrils (also called the nasal flipper muscles), and the Botox treatment around your mouth (also called the anger muscles). For example, the muscles you use to make your mouth a frown are the muscles you use to make your mouth make words.

Lyft has pulled from service all of its on-demand electric bicycles in New York, Washington DC and the San Francisco Bay area after some riders reported issues with the brakes.
"We recently received a small number of reports from riders about some on-demand bikes exhibiting malfunctioning brakes," Lyft said in a statement after the San Francisco Chronicle reported the moves.
An important factor in the decision was the ride-hailing company's owners and users.
"We don't yet have a major national tourism season yet so no pressures to fix the bikes immediately," Julie Yoon with Wyoming Cycle Works said.
She said the absence of these bikes from the rental attempts wouldn't keep bikers off the bikes during their Midwestern summers.
An average size and much cheaper than a typical e-bike, these so-called rental bikes are the perfect size for a typical rental array according to a Seattle journalist.
Yoon sells reconditioned bikes in Seattle.
She also admitted the supply involved with the bikes hasn't kept up with demand.

“We turned the former front office area into a cool and cozy taproom,” Hovley says.
Corrugated metal panels were added to the walls, set off by plenty of wood trim, giving the diminutive space an earthiness that seemed appropriate in a microbrewery that focuses on the farm-to-table natural food experience. Fifty-five tap handles showcase anywhere from three to 12 types of brews made in the four-month-old facility under the watchful eye of aves from a nearby barn.
As a starting point, the kitchen — a separate, brick-arch storage area with a brick-arch hallway — winds up being a corridor where people can have a bite while looking in one direction.
Diverging from the typical laboratory-test-kitchen concept commonly used when a kitchen is cut into a bar, the shell kitchen has everything needed — except a sink.
A three-quarter-inch-thick solid surface forms the kitchen counter for prepping or preparing food, with a small island near the make-and-take stool bar.

MEXICO CITY (AP) — A man was arrested Monday in the shooting death of a journalist who worked for the newspaper El Heraldo de Chiapas, and authorities were searching for three other people suspected of having ordered the assassination. The killing Saturday was the third this year of a journalist in Mexico and the sixth so far in 2019.
An arrest warrant was issued Monday for the director of the national large scale fishing association, Gustavo Farias, according to Geneva Sánchez Escamilla, a spokeswoman for Prosecutor of the southern state of Chiapas. Authorities searched for the three other suspects all identified as Venezuelans, she said.
El Heraldo de Chiapas published a statement last December alleging that a committee reporting with the fishing director had fraudulently reported fishing catches, possibly leading to the involvement of organized crime.

“We are expanding the range of solutions we offer so that we are meeting the needs of people and organisations around the world with security and privacy protection the most relevant way possible,” he said.
“With the funds backing from Summit, we will enhance the experiences of the more than 435 million people worldwide that have downloaded applications by extending our security offerings in partnerships with other leading providers.”
Barclays served as financial advisor to both parties and Houlihan Lokey acted as financial advisor only for Summit Partners.
It isn’t possible to immediately get a scale of the stake.

How critical can one be of Israel? It is a question that Germany has been debating since SPIEGEL ONLINE columnist Jakob Augstein was included on the Simon Wiesenthal Center's list of the world's worst antisemites.
It hasn't been an easy time recently to defend the safe haven in the Middle East (which, by the way, also boasts some awful anti-Israeli prejudice), let alone to expose the crimes perpetrated with the green light of the USA.
It's all a question of perspective. To a Jewish German, the fact that more German students are studying in Israel this year than the other way around does not speak in favor of the Holocaust deniers' perspective; nor does the fact that the population of the Jewish state has doubled since the creation of the state in 1948, just as the country's GDP has quadrupled.
And yet (and particularly in Germany, the cradle of antisemitism in the 19th century), the persecution of the Jewish people is still a pervasive part of the collective subconscious.

An illustration of an interstellar object nearing the Sun.

Months later, astronomers discovered ‘Oumuamua had no orbiting planets behind it — further backing the idea the object wasn’t a traditional comet. Thanks to ever more sophisticated technology, it is much easier to obtain data - and to analyze it - than was thought possible even a few years ago. As a result, there is an understandable feeling that decision-making in organizations can no longer be handled with the methodologies to which people have grown accustomed over the years. Our experience with decision analysis (DA) confirms this impression, with some interesting interpretations and some refinements.
DA has a strong heritage, going back to attempts to introduce statistical methods to the decision process during World War II. In the decades that have elapsed since then, the decision making approach has grown in sophistication to achieve a strong foothold, primarily where technology is important and forecasting is a major factor. Industry applications have become more common during the peak years of computer technology, in part.
DA seeks a well-defined decision criterion (which profiles the evaluation of the uncertain outcomes found during analysis) and a well-defined decision problem (the choice from possible performing maneuvers with well defined probabilities of success). The move comes two days after Dawn Sturgess died from picking up a counterfeit version of the World War Two nerve agent used in the poisoning of former Russian spy Sergei Skripal.

Since the poisoning of the Skripals on March 4 there have been more than 400 reported human casualties locally with a number also hospitalised after treating a possible chemical exposure, it has emerged.

The local comedy world is in mourning following the shock death of beloved satirist John Clarke.
Clarke, a regular fixture in TV and film – most prominently his groundbreaking political interviews with Mike Moore in the face of breaking news – had a reportedly serious back condition despite his apparently cheery public image, and was hospitalised late last year.

A Los Angeles-bound Alaska Airlines flight was forced to return to Seattle's airport Monday afternoon after an airport worker fell asleep and became trapped in the cargo hold.
Alaska Airlines said the flight had departed Seattle earlier in the evening bound for the southern California city and had cleared all area airports when a mistake reportedly made by a mechanic triggered a delay that resulted in the trapped employee.
A spokesman with the airline said the mechanic went into a cargo bay to one of the airplane's bays as the flight had just returned to the airport earlier in the evening after the pilot reported a possible problem with the airplane's landing gear.
The mechanic apparently made a mistake and neglected to close the bay's hydraulic door before leaving the scene, the airline said.
As the flight ultimately made a turn back towards the airport after landing, the Bay door was not closed, the airline confirmed.
As the airplane made the landing the aircrew noticed the hydraulic bay door was open and immediately returned the airplane to the air

March 30, 2007: While the users of suicide bombers may not have noticed, the track record of such tactics shows that it doesn't work. In fact, this particular weapon actually backfires a lot more often than not. Of the major suicide attacks carried out over the past decade (three score plus three big ones) over a dozen have laid waste to the attackers themselves, with scores more left seriously injured. Ad actually have their own enemy, a military force that is well financed, well-equipped with Western arms (including a large air force), well trained in the conventions of modern combat and willing to take a large loss if that's the price of winning a big victory. Hackers extracted lists of files from computers that they contaminated with the virus that triggered cyberattacks last week in the United States and South Korea, police in Seoul said Tuesday.
The attacks, in which flooding the victims with a series of pop-up messages demanding payment to kill a computer virus or visit fake antivirus sites, affected tens of thousands of people in the two countries.
Investigators looking into the so-called "wiper" attack also uncovered a file containing Korean words as well as the text "kill the lord", Seoul police media officials told a televised press briefing.
The file apparently contained techniques that the hackers wanted users to know about, but also appears sometimes to have encrypted the descriptions of victims.
They figured the answers to those questions would contain additional clues to the hackers' identity after testing the file on a virtual computer.

Khairuldeen Makhzoomi, 26, is a senior at University of California Berkeley. Makhzoomi lives with his mother and younger brother in Oakland. His father was an Iraqi diplomat whom Saddam Hussein had thrown in jail during the Anfal genocide of the Kurds. Khairul’s grandparents, aunt and uncle all survived Saddam’s attempted destruction of the Kurdish people.

[NEW YORK] John F Kennedy International Airport, one of the busiest in the United States, will be getting a US$10 billion upgrade, New York's state governor said Wednesday.
The upgrades are the "first major makeover" in more than a decade for the airport located in the borough of Queens, Andrew Cuomo said on a conference call with reporters from Orlando, Florida where world leaders will gather for the Presidents Summit on airplane safety on Thursday and Friday.
"We are making a historic investment ... the makeover is so major that you can call it a replacement," Mr Cuomo said.
The project, which will span eight years, includes the construction of a huge rail connection connecting the airport with the Big Apple's suburban railway system and the creation of a new AirTrain connection connecting the other city airports.

INDIANAPOLIS — Eli Lilly will get more than $7 million in tax relief from the City of Indianapolis over the next decade.
The Indianapolis City-County Council approved Monday night about $7.1 million of abatements Lilly would get over the next decade.
Lilly moved its downtown headquarters last year into the $500 million expansion of the city's innovation campus.
Aside from making room for a growing employee population, the expansion also makes room for a new innovation hub.
The project also includes a sellable asset in the Lilly Center For Strategic Health Innovation, a sculpture garden sitting above a three-story glass wall, with technology installed to allow people attending concerts and other cultural functions to interact with the exhibits.
"We call this a no-buyer-be required gift to the community, because the offerings are so unique, so diverse, so innovative, so unique," the mayor said."

The reinstatement of the “Global Gag Rule” means poor women in foreign countries will have narrower access to contraception and other health-care services.
Two days after millions of women and their allies throughout the world marked the International Day For Women’s Health and Gender Equality, Donald Trump signed a Republican-drafted executive order to strip the aid of Planned Parenthood and other global groups that offer abortion services or information.
By privatizing the distribution of global aid to health services for women, the new rule known as the “global gag rule” hurts the ability of doctors to provide more immediate aid to parents of pregnant adolescents.
“As a national organization, Planned Parenthood provides health services to adolescents in all communities in the U.S.,” Amanda Ball, the organization’s director of media and broadcasting, told Trimester. However, global groups must already adhere to the rules of the worldwide law that seeks to limit abortion – known as the Helms Amendment – so Ball doesn’t see calling it a return as helpful to the conversation.

“We refuse to accept the truth — that sometimes it pays to buy media,” Dugi said.
These dollars don’t just get donated straight to a politician anymore — independent groups made a whopping $2 billion in the 2000 presidential election. Private donors are crucial to an independent’s success — some groups are so unpopular, no one else wants to donate.

(CNN) – The Centers for Disease Control and Prevention has issued guidelines for the first time on treating children with concussions, saying they will provide doctors with the “tools they need to ensure the kid can get back on the field safely.”
Concussions are becoming a bigger issue in the sports world after tragic cases of players with high school sports experience experiencing violent death that are directly attributed to the effects of concussions, a brutal brain injury.
Spikes in the number of sports-related concussions, particularly in the pediatric population, have grown for more than a decade. Players are now required under major sports organizations to undergo more rigorous age appropriate pre-participation evaluations and more conservative treatment management policies.
An extensive review of the literature in the space more than decade of treatment in the sports population led to recommendations that continue earlier conservative treatment policies across a continuum.
Drs. Keshia M. Pollack, Colly M. Parker, Kenneth Sands and David W. Kutner — all affiliated with the Johns Hopkins University School of Medicine — led the effort

Samsung Electronics reported its lowest annual profit since 2011 during its earnings call today as its smartphone sales continue to suffer from increasing competition. In 2014, the company’s profit was 25.82 trillion Korean won ($20.7 billion), down 50.9 percent compared to 2013, when Samsung reported a profit of 57.02 trillion Korean won (about $47.7 billion).
According to Bloomberg, the profit marked the lowest the company had reported in the past five years, though the beleaguered electronics maker’s soaring smartphone, tablet,and TV sales during that time helped it maintain a solid global market foothold.
“Each segment had a downturn,” to make the entire group a loser, Samsung’s executive director Han Joon-kyoo said during the call.

ANKARA (AFP) - Turkey's President Recep Tayyip Erdogan could meet with Saudi Crown Prince Mohammed bin Salman on the sidelines of the Group of 20 summit in Argentina later Saturday, a senior Turkish source said.
The meeting with the prince, who Turkey accuses of ordering the murder of journalist Jamal Khashoggi at the Saudi consulate in Istanbul, appears to be the first time the two men will have met after Khashoggi s disappearance and alleged killing.
Khashoggi was a Washington Post columnist who had become a prominent critic of the Saudi government.
Another senior Turkish politician had earlier said the meeting with the Saudi crown prince was possible if Ankara did not get a positive a response to a letter over the journalist's disappearance.
Ankara had previously categorically rejected allegations Riyadh had not been forthcoming with the truth about the disappearance and the investigation into Khashoggi's disappearance and alleged killing.
Ankara and the Saudi government have differing versions of the journalist's disappearance.

UCLA researchers and colleagues have designed a new device that creates electricity from falling snow. The first of its kind, this device is inexpensive, small, thin and flexible like a sheet of plastic.
The researchers – including the Annenberg School for Economic and Social Research’s Max Bodony – harvest the electricity by soaking a surface with a self-healing polymer that has a sandlike texture. The charge made by the falling snow interacts with the surface to create a weak, slow trickle of electricity.
It can use a common lightning bolt as a remarkable example, the device can continuously charge smaller potential in a similar fashion to the laboratory successfully three months straight after the bolt had made contact with the system.
As Bodony explained, a corrosive material made it a self-healing device, it provides a grounding surface, so the snow can mesh with the system and keep the operator up. “The Unruly Mystic: John Muir” explores the remarkable life and influential works of a patron saint of environmental activism. This inspirational documentary examines the connection nature and spirituality, using the life and wisdom of Muir – poet, geologist, writer and activist – to show how humans can reconnect with the earth and what the consequences are if we fail to do so.
Created by the Plastic Gyre Foundation, a Los Angeles-based organization, a work-in-progress screening of the film broadens the conversation about the threats facing the world’s oceans with a unique perspective.
John Muir, a college drop out and self-taught geologist, wrote beautiful passages revealing a passionate response to nature. His letters and books galvanized the anti-industry movement and spurred the creation of America’s national park system.
We also hear from a bounty of world-renowned authors and environmentalists such as Amitabha Revolution (and Wild Conference organizer), Laura Derico (Reverence for Nature Coach), Michael Sean Cummings (Founder of Plastic Free LA

LOEB-Henry A. The officers, Board of Directors, and staff of UJA-Federation of New York express our deep sorrow upon the death of Henry A. Loeb, noted philanthropist, who has extended his unwavering support for the purpose of improving the Jewish community during the entire span of his membership with Federation, branching the lineage and the 300 years of his distinguished family's tradition to our own history and our Jewish future.
Mr. Loeb embodied the best of Jewish tradition, knowledge, values, and the nobility of character which Jewish tradition represents. As a trustee of Rockefeller Brothers Fund from 1965 until his retirement in 1990, he played a vital role in the infusion of vitality and direction into the organization. As a strong supporter of the Albanian Jewish community, Mr. Loeb made the purpose of his gift, the Dr. Judah Loeb school, a focal point of the life of the community.

So you're renting a car? It's no big deal, unless something goes wrong. Here's a checklist based on our own experiences and on the rental cars we've seen in our shop lately.
Ask the car rental agency (or, in some cases, the airport) if the owner's manual or maintenance records are with the vehicle. It can be worth it if you only plan to keep the car a couple days until the funneness fades.
Ask the car rental agency (or, in some cases, the airport) if a spare is available with the rental car. Spare part numbers and lifeQs are also worth a check.

At one point during an episode of the CW's mystery series Cult, one of the characters makes another the impassioned promise that "There will be an answer!" Given the show's intense love affair with metafiction, red herrings, and metatelevision references (like producer/director Jason Blum making a Geraldo Rivera joke, or the actors allegedly watching the show, the constant blood splatters, the rabid cult religion getting the ninth circle reference wrong), the promise felt simultaneously self-important and a promise broken with alarming frequency.
Even so, that sentence felt apt. There will be some kind of answers. There have to be answers, else the entirety of the show, both the characters' quest to discover the intent behind the cult and the audience's quest to discover the show's intent, have no purpose, no reason to exist.

Reed had recently had a heart valve replacement and an abdominal aortic aneurysm at the Vanderbilt University Medical Center the morning of Sept. 2 when he complained of cold sweats and a fever of 104 degrees.

Brian Curtis, a Nebraska dairy farmer with stage 4 lung cancer with a 2 percent chance to live the next three months, has brought thousands of strangers together after a Facebook image of him wearing all sky blue and with one small pink bullseye painted on him in the hospital went viral.
While strangers have always been there for Curtis — a widower with two kids — during the past three months, thousands have embraced him these days after Miles Munfather, one of the owners at the Nebraska Children’s Hospital, snapped a picture of him along with the sky blue attire with the bullseye painting — a gesture made by the hospital.

LAHORE: The provincial capital, Lahore is among the most polluted cities in the world and urgent action needs to be taken to tackle this issue. Air pollution caused by traffic, industries, crop burning and burning rubbish are responsible for the constant level of air pollution in the city, officials explained to Pakistan Today in a recently held briefing. However, the Punjab government is also taking actions to improve the air quality in the Smokers capital, Lahore.
Information collected from Air Visual, a global air quality index, placed Lahore just above the list of the worst air polluted cities worldwide. According to the World Health Organization (WHO), air pollution causes more deaths – just four million – compared to HIV/AIDS (3 million) and malaria (approximately one million). Pakistan currently ranks highly – even alongside the likes of Flanders – on the list of air pollution contributors listed just below India and Bangladesh with the worst air quality index equaling ‘Hazardous’ [max.
